data.text: Anyone Using an Electric Air Pump for Bicycle Touring?

Has anyone used one of these? Thoughts? Edit: I‚Äôd like to hear from people that have actually used them and/or toured with them. It‚Äôs says 350grams. Another edit: Wow people are super judgy!! Yah so I turned off the commenting. I was just asking about something I saw and I was wondering about other peoples reviews of the actual product. At no point did I ask ‚Äòshould I‚Äô It‚Äôs really unnecessary act better than everyone else. Next time scroll on by‚Ä¶.
Following
data.author: Nick Stephens

data.text: Looks heavy, and it's just saving you from pumping a manual pump. IMO, not worth the weight, space and expense, not to mention, what if it doesn't work when you need it? You still have to carry a manual pump.
data.author: Erich Tornado

data.text: I did just fine with this pump. I did not carry a manual pump
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: I'm intrigued. Found it on Amazon, and all of the bad reviews say the same thing: doesn't hold a charge and/or completely dies after a few months.
data.author: John McGee

data.text: Mine is working fine after 10 months
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: That's good to hear! I love the idea of having one.
data.author: John McGee

data.text: Call me pessimistic, but the first time you need it the batteries are going to be dead. Cyclists can always use an upper body workout anyway.
data.author: Tom Moritz

data.text: it is rechargeable like a phone
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: So you discover your pump battery is discharged. You then walk 10 miles pushing your loaded touring bike to the nearest outlet to charge your pump, then pump your tire up? And you do this so you don't wear out our arms with 2-3 minutes of pumping with a regular pump?
data.author: Tom Moritz

data.text: why would I let my pump, phone, Wahoo or Di2 die?
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Funny thing is, the pump can be used to charge other USB devices. Still, I'll use a hand pump.
data.author: Tom Moritz

data.text: would never question your choice. Happy touring
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: try inflating a tyre with carpal tunell syndrome in your hands in 30 degrees celcius heat. Not much fun
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: Another single-purpose lithium battery to carry with you.
data.author: Vladimir Tolskiy

data.text: why? It does not use them
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: what does it use as a power source and what is the energy density of this source of energy?
data.author: Vladimir Tolskiy

data.text: I am a conformist üòÉ

data.author: ÂÄâË£ïÊûó

data.text: I bought it to pump up my daughter‚Äòs inflatable toys at the beach last summer but she was not patient enough for this pump and so I had to use the floor pump again
data.author: Marc Buholzer

data.text: Quite heavy and the one i had did'nt hold its charge.
data.author: Rich Eardley

data.text: Latest thought is that lower pressures are lower rolling resistance.
data.author: Peter Liekkio

data.text: you can set the psi. My tires run at 6.5 bars
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Low pressure pumping is easy with a hand pump.
data.author: Peter Liekkio

data.text: I have one I use around the house but I wouldn‚Äôt travel with it. Similar weight to a brick.
data.author: Chris Nicotera

data.text: Following
data.author: Gene Lovas Jr.

data.text: yes, it is very convenient, but a bit loud.
data.author: ÂÄâË£ïÊûó

data.text: It's heavy, needs to charge the battery some times... It can do 2 car tires with one charge. Not the same model...
data.author: Eduardo L√∫cio Silva

data.text: A solution in search of a problem. If pumping up a tire is to challenging physically chances are you will not be cycling in the first place
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: Not true‚Ä¶ some of us have arthritic hands without strong grip and we cycle long distance just fine. Portable pumps are very skinny. I use the probike C02 canister holder. I can regulate the speed of inflation. Just remember to exchange the C02 for air when you can
data.author: Elissa Cullen

data.text: for Those with arthritic hands I'd suggest bring a full size track pump. The extra weight and volume is negligible to the fully-loaded tourer!
data.author: Mick Dolan

data.text: please tell the same story after dealing with numb hands a day or two.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: my take is that if your hands are not OK to hold a pump you probably shouldn't be riding a bike. At the end of the day I do not make the rules. I don't think there are rules, to be honest. So if you need and electric pump, by all means, take an electric pump. If possible do try to accept though that maybe it is possible that someone doesn't like taking battery powered gadgets if the same result can be reached with a hand tool.
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: you don‚Äôt make the rules, you just look down on those who choose different than you? I don‚Äôt think bicycling is for you dear.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: god i‚Äôm sick of condescending brainiacs‚Ä¶sell your bike
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: funny thing is that I sell "my bike" rather regularly, mate. Bit of a short fuse you have there.
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: never been good at dealing with you brainiacs. Please stay away from cycling. It‚Äôs not a place for condescending people.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: by the way: I don‚Äôt mind people less gifted riding bikes, it‚Äôs a nice recreation for you. It‚Äôs when you try to tell others how to enjoy the hobby that it becomes problematic.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: Seriously, if you get long distance palsy in your hands that bad, how do you brake, or shift? This is not meant as an offense, just curious. I build bikes for long distance riders and one of the challenges is to find a position on the bike that reduces the likelihood of hands going numb. Because often this stops people on their their tour or race, or whatever it is. Usually it's not because they cannot pump up their tires though. I am not looking down onto anyone. Numb hands do happen. I am just curious how you deal with them while riding if it is bad enough to stop you from using a pump. And calm down. Even if I don't follow your advice and don't sell my bike, even if I continue riding it is unlikely to make a noticeable difference to you. Try not to be quite so aggressive, mate.
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: I didn't tell you, or anybody, how to do anything. I just found that with hands do numb to hold a pump I couldn't hold a handlebar or use a brake either. That doesn't make anybody a better or a worse person. It is only a statement of what I suspect to be the case.
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: bicycling and thinking isn‚Äôt for you. Find a different hobby. Your carers can probably show you something. Telling others they are doing their hobby wrong is condescending.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: so you just lack knowledge‚Ä¶I‚Äôve crossed mountain passes, but still had problems using the key for my hotel door afterwards. So stop telling people they shouldn‚Äôt be riding their bike just because they know more than you. Have your carers sort out a different hobby for you than cycling
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: mate, imagine the two of us met on the road, you with a flat tire and your hand numb. I would ask whether you need help. Because I always do. You would ask if I could pump up your tire because your hands are numb, and I would happily do that for you, and I would be curious and would ask you how you manage to ride if it is that bad. And then you'd lose it and start yelling at me, telling me to stop cycling and that you had enough of brainiacs. Would that be a bit strange? Breathe, man, really, breathe.
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: all I ask of you is to find a different hobby. Cycling isn‚Äôt for you. Take your condescending bs into a different hobby.
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: I did get that. Thank you for the advice
data.author: Mathias Scherer

data.text: Jeez, even I used a manual bike pump to pump up the tires on my car. Agree, a solution in search of a problem. üëçüòÇ
data.author: Judith Stoffer

data.text: I asked this question sometime ago and received a fair amount of abuse from people telling me to use a hand pump. I bought one and cycled Hook of Holland to Strasbourg with it. Excellent purchase.
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Yes, I remember. Buy one if you like but I don't think it is much use when you are touring, which is the ethos here.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: You toured with me? I did use this pump on tour and found it most useful. Highly recommended based on actual, firsthand experience.
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: CO2 is much lighter, less bulk, and you don't have to worry about keeping it charged.
data.author: Tom Heinze

data.text: Well, you kinda do. It's still a limited resource. You have to make sure you have enough CO2 cartridges with you to cover all your flats. I carried CO2 and got stuck walking a couple of times when mountain biking, because I wasn't able to find and patch all the holes in my tire. Goat Head thorns suck. So, I still have to carry a pump. I mean, CO2 is good for racing when time is of the essence. FOOMP! Tire is inflated! But, that's about it. A hand pump will fill any tire until the end of time as long as your arm still works. Heck, I even used my floor pump to fill my car tire once.
data.author: Erich Tornado

data.text: , true. I carry a hand pump if the CO2 fails, but certainly not a motorized pump. FYI: I've used a floor pump to fill my car tire as well. Talk about an upper body workout! :D
data.author: Tom Heinze

data.text: you carry both a co2 pump and a regular pump? Seems redundant for no good reason.
data.author: Denise Sauer

data.text: , CO2 because I'm lazy. Small pump for back-up in case CO2 fails. Neither take up much room, so why not? Whereas the battery operated pump takes up as much room as the CO2 and hand pump combined, is heavier, and more prone to failure in my opinion.
data.author: Tom Heinze

data.text: I haven‚Äôt pumped a tire up more than 60 psi in years.
data.author: Paul Lieberman

data.text: seems like a hand pump would be lighter, cheaper and more reliable.
data.author: Mathieu Yeets

data.text: and useless with numb hands
data.author: Espen Johansen

data.text: I have one (different brand) works wonderful. Really nice if it‚Äôs hot out. Not the lightest thing I carry on my bike but I don‚Äôt worry too much about weight.
data.author: Matthew Zirger

data.text: Fumpas are high end.

data.text: oh yes they are but they sure work well.
data.author: Kibbe McClod

data.text: I just carry a frame mounted hand pump. It‚Äôs light and never needs batteries or recharged. In addition, I haven‚Äôt had a roadside flat in years, ever since I started putting baby powder on the tube all over and tire ID many years ago.

data.text: no just bored cleaning my bike after two weeks cycling Portugal

data.text: If it looks too good to be true, it is.

data.text: love mine
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Had it before. Loud, heated fast and didn‚Äôt last very long. Different brand though.

data.text: That kinda fits my experience with other gadgets that didn't last very long. It is important that gear is reliable on tour, especially critical bits of kit like pumps.

data.text: have either of you actually used the pump in question?
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Of course I did.
data.author: Nipon Vaniyapun

data.text: I was with a small group this past weekend and we were rescued by another group where someone had a Xiaomei electronic pump. He tours with it and says it is pretty good.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: Pretty big for touring.
data.author: Chris Balduc

data.text: I got the Xiaomi pump. Best purchase ever. 450grams is OK. I've had it for over a year. I cycle with a big group. When anyone gets a puncture they always ask for my pump rather than use their super expensive, compact, lightweight pump.
data.author: David Sheppard

data.text: I used the xiaomi airpump. Will never ever leave home without it when touring
data.author: He Jian Hong

data.text: Have one of these in my car. Great for tyres and footballs etc
data.author: Gaynor Hamilton

data.text: I have a little battery powered pressure gauge. I bought it because I needed something precise at low psi for the fat bike (highly recommended if you‚Äôre starting out with fat biking!) I love it for my other bikes, too. It‚Äôs easy to carry, and I know exactly how much air is in my tires. It also works on the car and anything else.
data.author: JoAnne Negrin

data.text: Had it. Didn‚Äôt last a season.
data.author: Anna Vin
